entry.title: Galois Correspondences I
entry.content:
In this post, we discuss the fundamental theorem of Galois theory along the consideration of Galois connections.

Galois Connections

Definition: An (antitone) Galois connection is a dual adjunction between posets. In other words, a Galois connection consists of the following data:

  • Two posets A,BA, BA,B,
  • Two order-reversing maps f:A→Bf:A\to Bf:A→B and g:B→Ag:B\to Ag:B→A ,
    such that
  • a≤g(f(a))a\le g(f(a))a≤g(f(a)) and b≤f(g(b))b\le f(g(b))b≤f(g(b)) for all a∈Aa\in Aa∈A, b∈Bb\in Bb∈B.

One can see that fff and ggg automatically satisfy the triangle identities: $$f\circ g\circ f = f, \qquad g\circ f\circ g = g,$$ and thus form a dual adjunction between posets.

Definition: An (antitone) Galois correspondence is a dual adjoint equivalence between posets, that is a Galois connection such that f∘g=1f\circ g = 1f∘g=1 and g∘f=1g\circ f = 1g∘f=1.

One can verify the following basic fact.
Proposision: Any Galois connection (A,B,f,g)(A,B,f,g)(A,B,f,g) induces a Galois correspondence (g(B),f(A),f,g)(g(B),f(A),f,g)(g(B),f(A),f,g).

Recall that a dual adjoint functor maps colimits to limits and gives canonical morphisms from colimits to the image of limits. Thus we have
Proposision: Let (A,B,f,g)(A,B,f,g)(A,B,f,g) be a Galois connection. Then for any ai∈A,bj∈Ba_i\in A, b_j\in Bai​∈A,bj​∈B, we have

\begin{align*} f(\sup \{a_i\}) = \inf\{f(a_i)\}, &\quad& f(\inf\{a_i\}) \ge \sup\{f(a_i)\},\\ g(\sup\{b_j\}) = \inf\{g(b_j)\}, &\quad& g(\inf\{b_j\}) \ge \sup\{g(b_j)\}. \end{align*}

Remark: One can also consider the notions of monotone Galois connections and monotone Galois correspondences.

Galois Groups and Galois Extensions

Now we apply the above to algebraic field extensions. So throughout this section, every field extension is assumed to be algebraic.

First Galois Correspondence

First, we have the folloing Galois connection:

\begin{align*} \{\text{subgroups of }\mathrm{Aut}(K)\} & \longleftrightarrow \{\text{subfields of }K\}.\\ G & \longrightarrow K^G \\ \mathrm{Gal}(K/F) & \longleftarrow F. \end{align*}

Here we use Gal(K/F)\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)Gal(K/F) to denote the group of automorphisms of KKK fixing FFF.

We define
Definition: A subgroup GGG of Aut(K)\mathrm{Aut}(K)Aut(K) is called a Galois group if G=Gal(K/F)G=\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)G=Gal(K/F), where FFF is a subfield of KKK. A field extension K/FK/FK/F is called a Galois extension if F=KGF=K^GF=KG, where GGG is a subgroup of Aut(K)\mathrm{Aut}(K)Aut(K).

Then we obtain the Galois corresponding between Galois groups and Galois extensions. However, this correpondence is not the one the fundamental theorem of Galois theory states. To get it, we need to look closer. For the field extension side, we need to show that if K/FK/FK/F is a Galois extension, then so are all K/EK/EK/E where EEE is an intermediate field of K/FK/FK/F. This follows immediately once one proves the following lemma.

Lemma: A field extension is a Galois extension if and only if it is the splitting field of a family of separable polynomials.
Note that, from this, one can see any Galois extension must be a separable extension.

For the subgroup side, one only need to notice that the Galois subgroups must be closed. Then, we get the Galois correspondence for a Galois extension K/FK/FK/F:

\begin{align*} \{\text{closed subgroups of }\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)\} & \longleftrightarrow \{\text{intermediate fields of }K/F\}.\\ H & \longrightarrow K^H\\ \mathrm{Gal}(K/E) & \longleftarrow E. \end{align*}

Note that under this corresponding, open subgroups of Gal(K/F)\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)Gal(K/F) correspond finite subextensions of K/FK/FK/F.

Second Galois Correspondence

Now, we restrict the map H↦KHH\mapsto K^HH↦KH to the subposet of normal subgroups of Gal(K/F)\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)Gal(K/F) and identify it with the opposite of the poset of quotient of Gal(K/F)\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)Gal(K/F). Then, we have the following order-reversing map

\begin{align*} \{\text{quotients of }\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)\} & \longleftrightarrow \{\text{intermediate fields of }K/F\}.\\ \mathrm{Gal}(K/F)/H & \longmapsto K^H. \end{align*}

One can see

Gal(KH/F)=Gal(K/F)/H.\mathrm{Gal}(K^H/F) = \mathrm{Gal}(K/F)/H. Gal(KH/F)=Gal(K/F)/H.

In other word, Gal(KH/F)\mathrm{Gal}(K^H/F)Gal(KH/F) is a quotient of Gal(K/F)\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)Gal(K/F) with kernel HHH.

For an arbitrary field extension E/FE/FE/F, there is no need to be an epimorphism

Gal(F)⟶Gal(E/F).\mathrm{Gal}(F)\longrightarrow\mathrm{Gal}(E/F). Gal(F)⟶Gal(E/F).

Here Gal(F)\mathrm{Gal}(F)Gal(F) denotes the absolutely Galois group Gal(Falg/F)\mathrm{Gal}(F_{\mathrm{alg}}/F)Gal(Falg​/F).

Note that, Gal(Falg/F)=Gal(Fsep/F)\mathrm{Gal}(F_{\mathrm{alg}}/F) = \mathrm{Gal}(F_{\mathrm{sep}}/F)Gal(Falg​/F)=Gal(Fsep​/F), where FsepF_{\mathrm{sep}}Fsep​ is the separable closure of FFF and Fsep/FF_{\mathrm{sep}}/FFsep​/F is always Galois.

We define
Definition: A field extension E/FE/FE/F is call a normal extension if any embedding E→FalgE\to F_{\mathrm{alg}}E→Falg​ induces an automorphism of EEE over FFF.
One can see that Galois = normal + separable if one has known the following lemma.
Lemma: A field extension is a normal extension if and only if it is the splitting field of a family of polynomials.

Now, one can now see that if E/FE/FE/F is a normal extension, then there is a group homomorphism

\begin{align*} \mathrm{Gal}(F) & \longrightarrow \mathrm{Gal}(E/F). \\\ \sigma & \longmapsto \sigma|_E, \end{align*}

As any automorphism of a normal extension E/FE/FE/F can be extended into an automorphism of Falg/FF_{\mathrm{alg}}/FFalg​/F, the above homomorphism is surjective. The kernel of it is obviously the absolutely Galois group Gal(E)\mathrm{Gal}(E)Gal(E).

In this way, we get a Galois connection:

\begin{align*} \{\text{quotients of }\mathrm{Gal}(F)\} & \longleftrightarrow \{\text{normal extensions of }F\}.\\ \mathrm{Gal}(F)/H & \longrightarrow F_{\mathrm{alg}}^H\\ \mathrm{Gal}(E) & \longleftarrow E. \end{align*}

Let K/FK/FK/F be another normal extension such that E⊂KE\subset KE⊂K. Then, by the Galois connection, we have

Gal(Falg/K)<Gal(Falg/E).\mathrm{Gal}(F_{\mathrm{alg}}/K)< \mathrm{Gal}(F_{\mathrm{alg}}/E). Gal(Falg​/K)<Gal(Falg​/E).

Therefore there is a homomorphism

\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)\longrightarrow\mathrm{Gal}(E/F). $$ fitting into the following commutative diagram

\begin{gather*}
\mathrm{Gal}(F_{\mathrm{alg}}/F) \
\swarrow\qquad\qquad\searrow \
\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)\longrightarrow\mathrm{Gal}(E/F)
\end{gather*}

and hence an epimorphism. In particular this holds for Galois extensions $K/F$. In this way, we get a Galois correspondence:

\begin{align*}
{\text{quotients of }\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)} & \longleftrightarrow
{\text{normal subextensions of }K/F}.\
\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)/H &
\longrightarrow K^H \
\mathrm{Gal}(K/E) &
\longleftarrow E.
\end{align*}

### The Degree Encoding Let $K/F$ be a field extension. The poset of closed subgroups of $G=\mathrm{Gal}(K/F)$ admits an order-preserving map $H\mapsto|H|$ and an order-reversing map $H\mapsto[G:H]$ to the poset of *supernatural numbers*. Moreover, we have

|G| = |H|\cdot[G:H].

Likewise, the poset of intermediate fields $E$ of $K/F$ admits an order-reversing map $E\mapsto[K:E]$ and an order-preserving map $E\mapsto[E:F]$ to the poset of supernatural numbers and we have

[K:F] = [K:E]\cdot[E:F].

The Galois correspondences suggest us to compare them. This is what Artin's theorem says. **Artin's Theorem:** Let $K$ be a field and $G$ a closed subgroup of $\mathrm{Aut}(K)$. Then

|G| = [K:K^G].

Note that when apply to Galois extensions $K/F$, the theorem implies

|H| = [K:K^H],
\quad\text{and}\quad
[G:H] = [K^H:F].

This post is long enough, so we may stop here. ## Reference For the missing notions and proofs in algebra, see any textbook such as - Serge Lang, *Algebra*, 3rd ed., Addison-Wesley, 1993. As for the infinite case of Galois theory, especially the notion of profinite groups and supernatural numbers, see - Michael D. Fried, Moshe Jarden, *Field Arithmetic*, Ergebnisse der Mathematik und ihrer Grenzgebiete 3, Folge 11 (3rd ed.), Springer-Verlag, 2008.

entry.title: Connectedness of Schemes
entry.content:
In this short post, we point out that the notion of connectedness of schemes is previously a special case of connected objects.

Infinitary extensive categories

Definition: A category C\mathcal{C}C is said to be infinitary extensive if it has all (small) coproducts such that pullbacks of coproduct injections along arbitrary morphisms exist and finite coproducts are disjoint and stable under pullback.

One can then image coproducts in such kind of categories as generalized disjoint unions. Typical examples are topoi and some geometric categories such as Top\mathrm{Top}Top and Diff\mathrm{Diff}Diff.

The category Sch\mathrm{Sch}Sch of schemes is also infinitary extensive, see here for discussion on this fact.

Connected schemes

We now discuss the notion of connectedness for schemes. Note that we always assume that connected spaces are nonempty. Recall that the coproducts in Top\mathrm{Top}Top and Sch\mathrm{Sch}Sch are just disjoint unions.

Definition: Let C\mathcal{C}C be an infinitary extensive category. Then an object XXX is called a connected object if the representable functor $$
\mathrm{Hom}(X,−)\colon\mathcal{C}\longrightarrow \mathrm{Set}

preserves binary coproducts. Note that if this is the case, then the above representable functor preserves all coproducts. **Definition:** A scheme $X$ is said to be **connected** if its underlying topological space is connected. We want to show **Theorem:** A scheme is connected if and only if it is a connected object. To prove this, recall the similar result for topological spaces. **Lemma:** A topological space is connected if and only if it is a connected object. **Proof:** Let $X$ be a connected space and $\\{Y_i\\}$ be a family of topological spaces. Then we always have an injective map $$\bigsqcup\mathrm{Hom}(X,Y\_i)\longrightarrow\mathrm{Hom}(X,\bigsqcup Y\_i).

As any continuous map must preserve connectedness, this map is also surjective.
Coversely, let X=Y1⊔Y2X=Y_1\sqcup Y_2X=Y1​⊔Y2​. Then the map

\mathrm{Hom}(X,Y\_1)\sqcup\mathrm{Hom}(X,Y\_2)\longrightarrow\mathrm{Hom}(X,X)$$ is not surjective since the identity $\mathrm{id}_{X}$ has no preimage. This shows $X$ can not be a connected object. Note that, the underlying map of any morphism of schemes is continuous, therefore the above proof works for the theorem with a bit modifocations. ## Reference https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/connected+object

entry.title: Galois Correspondences II
entry.content:
This time, we consider a more general case: we give the Galois correspondence for schemes over a field.

Preliminaries

First, we recall some notions and facts.

Adjunctions and adjoint equivalences

Definition: Let F ⁣:C→D,G ⁣:D→CF\colon\mathcal{C}\to\mathcal{D}, G\colon\mathcal{D}\to\mathcal{C}F:C→D,G:D→C be two functors. We call they form an adjuction if there exist two natrual transformations η ⁣:id→GF\eta\colon\mathrm{id} \to GFη:id→GF (called unit) and ϵ ⁣:FG→id\epsilon\colon FG \to \mathrm{id}ϵ:FG→id (called counit) such that the following two diagrams (called the triangle identities) hold.

FGFFη↗↖ϵGF⟶idFGFGηG↗↖FϵG⟶idG\begin{gathered} FGF \\ F\eta\nearrow\qquad\nwarrow\epsilon G \\ F\quad\stackrel{\mathrm{id}}{\longrightarrow}\quad F \end{gathered} \qquad\qquad \begin{gathered} GFG\\ \eta G\nearrow\qquad\nwarrow F\epsilon \\ G\quad\stackrel{\mathrm{id}}{\longrightarrow}\quad G \end{gathered} FGFFη↗↖ϵGF⟶id​F​GFGηG↗↖FϵG⟶id​G​

If furthermore both η\etaη and ϵ\epsilonϵ are isomorphisms, then F,GF,GF,G are equivalences of categories and we say they form a pair of adjoint equivalences.

Proposition: Let F ⁣:C→D,G ⁣:D→CF\colon\mathcal{C}\to\mathcal{D}, G\colon\mathcal{D}\to\mathcal{C}F:C→D,G:D→C be an adjunction with unit η\etaη and counit ϵ\epsilonϵ. Let Cη\mathcal{C}^{\eta}Cη be the full subcategory of C\mathcal{C}C consisting of those objects XXX such that ηX\eta_XηX​ is an isomorphism. Define Dϵ\mathcal{D}^{\epsilon}Dϵ likewise. Then FFF and GGG give rise to a pair of adjoint equivalences:

Cη≅Dϵ.\mathcal{C}^{\eta} \cong \mathcal{D}^{\epsilon}. Cη≅Dϵ.

GGG-sets and GGG-spaces

Definition: Let GGG be a group. A GGG-set is a set SSS together with a group action G×S→SG\times S\to SG×S→S. A GGG-map is a map of sets between GGG-sets compatible with the group actions. A GGG-subset of a GGG-set SSS is a subset TTT of SSS such that the inclusion T↪ST\hookrightarrow ST↪S is a GGG-map. Let s∈Ss\in Ss∈S, then

  • the GGG-subset Gs:={gs|g∈G}Gs:=\left\{gs \middle| g\in G\right\}Gs:={gs∣g∈G} is called the orbit of sss;
  • the subgroup Gs:={g∈G|gs=s}G_s:=\left\{ g\in G \middle| gs=s \right\}Gs​:={g∈G∣gs=s} is called the stabilizer of sss;
  • sss is said to be GGG-invariant if gs=sgs=sgs=s for all g∈Gg\in Gg∈G.

Let g∈Gg\in Gg∈G, then

  • the GGG-subset Sg:={s∈S|gs=s}S^g:=\left\{s\in S\middle|gs=s\right\}Sg:={s∈S∣gs=s} is called the set of fixed point of ggg.

Finally

  • the set of GGG-invariants is denoted by SGS^GSG, which equals ∩g∈GSg\cap_{g\in G} S^g∩g∈G​Sg,
  • the set of orbits is denoted by S/GS/GS/G and called the quotient of the action.

Fundamental theorem of GGG-sets: Let GGG be a group and SSS a GGG-set. Then SSS is a disjoint union of some orbits GsGsGs, which, as GGG-set, is isomorphic to the quotient G/GsG/G_sG/Gs​.

Remark: The above stories can be transplanted to some geometric categories C\mathcal{C}C. In this case, we should consider group objects GGG instead of groups and GGG-spaces instead of GGG-sets. In this case, we call the space of orbits S/GS/GS/G the orbit space. Examples include:

  • continuous actions of topological groups on topological spaces,
  • smooth actions of Lie groups on smooth manifolds,
  • regular actions of algebraic groups on algebraic varieties, and
  • actions of group schemes on schemes.

Remark: Let GGG be a topological group. Then we call a GGG-space SSS with discrete topology a GGG-set. Note that in thise case, the stabiliaer of any point is open.

Galois Theory For KKK-Schemes

Let KKK be a field and GGG be its absolute Galois group.

Definition: A KKK-scheme is a locally ringed space which is locally the spectrum of a KKK-algebra. Equivalently, a KKK-scheme XXX is a morphism of schemes X→Spec(K)X\to \mathrm{Spec}(K)X→Spec(K). A morphism of KKK-schemes is a morphism of schemes over Spec(K)\mathrm{Spec}(K)Spec(K).

Note that, there exists a continuous GGG-action on each set HomSpec(K)(Spec(Ksep),X)\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),X)HomSpec(K)​(Spec(Ksep​),X) for each KKK-scheme XXX:

\begin{align*} G\times\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),X\right) & \longrightarrow \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),X\right) \\ (g,f) & \longmapsto f\circ\widetilde{g}, \end{align*}

where g~\widetilde{g}g​ is the automoprhism of Spec(Ksep)\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}})Spec(Ksep​) induced by g ⁣:Ksep→Ksepg\colon K_{\mathrm{sep}}\to K_{\mathrm{sep}}g:Ksep​→Ksep​.

Those actions are compatible with the morphisms of KKK-schemes. Therefore, we get a functor

K-Sch⟶G-Set.K\text{-}\mathrm{Sch} \longrightarrow G\text{-}\mathrm{Set}. K-Sch⟶G-Set.

From GGG-sets to KKK-schemes

Let HHH be a subgroup of GGG, then KsepHK_{\mathrm{sep}}^HKsepH​ is an KKK-algebra. Since any homomorphism of KKK-algebras KsepH→KsepK_{\mathrm{sep}}^H\to K_{\mathrm{sep}}KsepH​→Ksep​ can be extended to an automorphism of KsepK_{\mathrm{sep}}Ksep​ over KKK, we have

\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^H)\right) = \mathrm{Hom}_K\left(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^H,K_{\mathrm{sep}}\right) \cong G/H $$ as $G$-sets. Let $S$ be a $G$-set and

S = \bigsqcup Gs

be all the distinct orbits of $S$. Then

X = \bigsqcup \mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_s})

is a $K$-scheme. Since $\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}})$ is a single point hence connected, the $G$-map

\eta_S\colon S = \bigsqcup Gs \cong \bigsqcup\mathrm{Hom}{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K{\mathrm{sep}}),\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_s})\right)\longrightarrow
\mathrm{Hom}{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K{\mathrm{sep}}),\bigsqcup\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_s})\right)

is bijective. Let $f\colon S\to T$ be a $G$-map and let $X, Y$ be the $F$-algebras associated to $S, T$ respectively. Then for any point $s\in S$, the stabilizer of $s$ is a subgroup of $f(s)$. Thus $K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_{f(s)}}$ is a subalgebra of $K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_s}$. This induces a morphism of $K$-schemes $X\to Y$. In this way, we get a functor

F\colon G\text{-}\mathrm{sets} \longrightarrow K\text{-}\mathrm{Sch}.

### From $K$-schemes to $G$-sets Let $X$ be a $K$-scheme and

\mathrm{Hom}{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K{\mathrm{sep}}),X\right) = \bigsqcup Gf

theorbitdecomposition.Let the orbit decomposition. Let theorbitdecomposition.Let

Y = \bigsqcup \mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_f}).

Let $f\colon\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}})\to X$ be a morphism of $K$-schemes. Then, for any open set $U$ of $X$ containing the image of $f$, the $K$-homomorphism $\mathcal{O}_X(U)\to K_{\mathrm{sep}}$ factors through $K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_f}$. Thus $f$ factors through $\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{G_f})$. Therefore we get a canonical morphism of $K$-schemes

\epsilon_X\colon Y\longrightarrow X.

### The adjunction From the above discussion, we have seen: - given a $G$-set $S$, there is a canonical bijective $G$-map $$\eta_S\colon S\longrightarrow\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),F(S)\right);

  • given a KKK-scheme XXX, there is a canonical morphism of KKK-schemes

    ϵX ⁣:F(HomSpec(K)(Spec(Ksep),X))⟶X.\epsilon_X\colon F(\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),X\right))\longrightarrow X. ϵX​:F(HomSpec(K)​(Spec(Ksep​),X))⟶X.

Moreover, one can verify that the above data satisfies the triangle identities. Thus we get an adjunction

F⊣HomSpec(K)(Spec(Ksep),−).F\dashv \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),-\right). F⊣HomSpec(K)​(Spec(Ksep​),−).

As ηS\eta_SηS​ is always bijective, we have (G-Set)η=G-Set(G\text{-}\mathrm{Set})^{\eta} = G\text{-}\mathrm{Set}(G-Set)η=G-Set. How about (K-Sch)ϵ(K\text{-}\mathrm{Sch})^{\epsilon}(K-Sch)ϵ?

Etale schemes

The essential iamge of the functor FFF can be characterised as follows.
Definition: A KKK-scheme is said to be étale if it is isomorphic to a disjoint union of sepctra of finite separable extensions of KKK.
This is of course not the original definition. One can image this as a lemma.

By the first Galois correspondence, any finite separable extension of KKK is of the form KHK^HKH where HHH is an open subgroup of GGG.

Let XXX be an étale KKK-scheme and

X≅⨆Spec(KsepHi).X \cong \bigsqcup \mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{H_i}). X≅⨆Spec(KsepHi​​).

Then we have

HomSpec(K)(Spec(Ksep),X)=⨆HomSpec(K)(Spec(Ksep),Spec(KsepHi)).\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),X\right)=\bigsqcup\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{H_i})\right). HomSpec(K)​(Spec(Ksep​),X)=⨆HomSpec(K)​(Spec(Ksep​),Spec(KsepHi​​)).

Note that each HomSpec(K)(Spec(Ksep),Spec(KsepHi))\mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{H_i})\right)HomSpec(K)​(Spec(Ksep​),Spec(KsepHi​​)) must be connected. Therefore $$F(\mathrm{Hom}{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K{\mathrm{sep}}),X\right)) = \bigsqcup \mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}^{H_i})$$ and hence the canonical morphism ϵX\epsilon_XϵX​ is an isomophism.

In this way, we see that (K-Sch)ϵ(K\text{-}\mathrm{Sch})^{\epsilon}(K-Sch)ϵ consists precisely the étale KKK-schemes.

Galois correspondence for KKK-schemes

Conclude above, we have
Theorem: Let KKK be a field and GGG be its absolute Galois group. Then there is a pair of adjoint equivalences of categories

F\dashv \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathrm{Spec}(K)}\left(\mathrm{Spec}(K_{\mathrm{sep}}),-\right). $$ between the category of $G$-sets and the category of étale $K$-schemes. Let $L/K$ be a Galois extension, then the above pair of adjoint equivalences induces a pair of adjoint of equivalences between the category of $\mathrm{Gal}(L/K)$-sets and the category of $K$-schemes which are isomorphic to disjoint unions of sepctra of finite subseparable extensions of $L/K$. ### Galois correspondence for $K$-algebras Note that finite disjoint union of affine schemes is the same as coproduct of them in the category of affine schemes, hence we have

\bigsqcup_{i=1}^{n}\mathrm{Spec}(L_i) = \mathrm{Spec}(\prod_{i=1}^{n}L_i).

Recall that a $K$-algebra is said to be **étale** if it is a finite product of finite separable extensions of $K$ and **splited** by $L$ is all those separable extensions are subextensions of the Galois extension $L/K$. Then one may expect a Galois correspondence for such kind of $K$-algebras. However, a finite disjoint union of $G$-sets may not be finite unless all the components are finite. So we have **Theorem:** Let $L/K$ be a finite Galois extension. Then the functor

\mathrm{Hom}_{K}\left(-,L\right)

is an equivalence between the category of finite $\mathrm{Gal}(L/K)$-sets and the category of finite $K$-algebras splited by $L$. Note that - any Galois extension is a filtered colimit of finite Galois extensions; - any $K$-algebra is a filtered colimit of finite subalgebras; - a $G$-space is said to be **profinite** if it is a filtered colimit of finite $G$-sets. We thus get **Theorem:** Let $L/K$ be a Galois extension. Then the functor

\mathrm{Hom}_{K}\left(-,L\right)

is an equivalence between the category of profinite $\mathrm{Gal}(L/K)$-spaces and the category of $K$-algebras splited by $L$. ### Etale coverings Recall that **Definition:** Let $X$ be a scheme. A family of morphisms $\\{f_i\colon Y_i\to X\\}$ is called a **étale covering** if all $f_i$ are étale and the images of $Y_i$ cover $X$. Equipped such coverings, $\mathrm{Sch}$ becomes a sites, call the **(big) étale site**, and $K\text{-}\mathrm{Sch}$ becomes a sites $\mathrm{Spec}(K)_{et}$, call the **(small) étale site** of $\mathrm{Spec}(K)$. One can verify that under the Galois correspondence for $K$-schemes, the étale coverings in the étale site $\mathrm{Spec}(K)_{et}$ correspond to surjective families of $G$-maps in $G\text{-}\mathrm{Set}$. Let's stop this post here. ## Reference For the notion of schemes, one can refer any textbooks such as - Robin Hartshorne, *Algebraic Geometry*, Graduate Texts in Mathematics 52, New York: Springer-Verlag, 1977. - Ravi Vakil, [*Math 216: Foundations of algebraic geometry*](https://math216.wordpress.com). - Johan de Jong, et al., [*Stack project*](http://stacks.math.columbia.edu).

entry.title: Galois Correspondences III
entry.content:
This time, we consider another kind of Galois correspondence: the one for covering spaces. This is actually somehow trivial.

Preliminaries

Let XXX be a topological space. We first recall some notions in topology.

Definition: A covering space YYY over XXX is a bundle p ⁣:Y→Xp\colon Y\to Xp:Y→X which is locally trival and with discrete fibers. In plain words, the condition means for every point x∈Xx\in Xx∈X, there exists an open neighborhood UUU such that the pullback p−1(U)→Up^{-1}(U)\to Up−1(U)→U is isomorphic to a projection U×F→UU\times F\to UU×F→U with FFF a nonempty discrete set.

\begin{gather*} p^{-1}(U) \stackrel{\cong}{\longrightarrow} U\times F \\ p\searrow\quad\swarrow\mathrm{pr} \\ U \end{gather*}

Definition: The fundamental group π(X,x)\pi(X,x)π(X,x) of XXX at a point x∈Xx\in Xx∈X is the group of homotopy classes of loops through xxx and lie in XXX.

Under the assumption that XXX is connected, locally path-connected and semi-locally simply-connected, the group π(X,x)\pi(X,x)π(X,x) is independent of the choice of xxx. In this case, we denote π(X)\pi(X)π(X) for short. However, we still need to fix a base point xxx. We will keep this assumption throughout this post.

Galois correspondence for covering spaces

From covering spaces to π(X)\pi(X)π(X)-sets

Let p ⁣:Y→Xp\colon Y\to Xp:Y→X be a covering space. Then p−1(x)p^{-1}(x)p−1(x) is a π(X)\pi(X)π(X)-set whose action is given as follows: the unique path-lifting lemma says that given a point y1∈p−1(x)y_1\in p^{-1}(x)y1​∈p−1(x), any loop ϕ\phiϕ in XXX start at xxx can be uniquely lifted to a path in YYY from y1y_1y1​ to another point y2∈p−1(x)y_2\in p^{-1}(x)y2​∈p−1(x). The homotopic loops give the same point y2y_2y2​, thus we define the result of the action of this homotopy class [ϕ][\phi][ϕ] on y1y_1y1​ to be y2y_2y2​.

Let f ⁣:Y→Y′f\colon Y\to Y'f:Y→Y′ be a morphism of covering spaces of XXX. Then it induces a continuous π(X)\pi(X)π(X)-map from p−1(x)p^{-1}(x)p−1(x) to p′−1(x)p'^{-1}(x)p′−1(x). In this way, we get a functor from the category Cov/X\mathrm{Cov}/XCov/X of covering spaces of XXX to the category of π(X)\pi(X)π(X)-sets:

Fx ⁣:Cov/X⟶π(X)-Set.\mathcal{F}_x\colon\mathrm{Cov}/X\longrightarrow\pi(X)\text{-}\mathrm{Set}. Fx​:Cov/X⟶π(X)-Set.

The universal covering space

Let X~\widetilde{X}X be the topological space whose underlying set is the set of all homotopy classes of paths in XXX starting at the base point xxx and whose topology is the weakest one making the following map continuous:

p ⁣:X~→X,[γ]↦γ(1).p\colon\widetilde{X}\to X,\quad [\gamma]\mapsto\gamma(1). p:X→X,[γ]↦γ(1).

For convenience, we fix the bas point x~\tilde{x}x~ of X~\widetilde{X}X to be the homotopy class of the trivial loops through xxx.

Then p ⁣:X~→Xp\colon\widetilde{X}\to Xp:X→X is the universal covering space of XXX in the sense that for any connected covering space Y→XY\to XY→X, there exists a morphism of covering spaces of XXX:

\begin{gather*} \widetilde{X} \stackrel{\exists!}{\longrightarrow} Y \\ \searrow\quad\swarrow \\ X \end{gather*}

and this morphism is unique if we require it to preserve the base points. When we choice y∈p−1(x)y\in p^{-1}(x)y∈p−1(x) to be the base point of YYY, the morphism is given as follows: the unique path-lifting lemma allows us to lift every path γ\gammaγ start at xxx in XXX to a path start at yyy in YYY, we define the image of [γ][\gamma][γ] to be the end of this path.

Note that the universal covering space naturally has a free π(X)\pi(X)π(X)-action given by composition of homotopy classes of paths. For any subgroup HHH of π(X)\pi(X)π(X), the orbit space X~/H\widetilde{X}/HX/H also gives a connected covering space of XXX whose fibers are isomorphic to π(X)/H\pi(X)/Hπ(X)/H.

From π(X)\pi(X)π(X)-sets to covering spaces

Let SSS be a π(X)\pi(X)π(X)-set. Then, we may write

S=⨆π(X)s.S = \bigsqcup \pi(X)s. S=⨆π(X)s.

We define

F(S) = \bigsqcup \widetilde{X}/\pi(X)_s, $$ and the bundle map $p\colon F(S)\to X$ is the one induced from the previous property of universal covering space. One can see the canonical $\pi(X)$-map

S\longrightarrow p^{-1}(x)

F\colon \pi(X)\text{-}\mathrm{Set}\longrightarrow\mathrm{Cov}/X.

### The equivalence Given a covering space $p\colon Y\to X$, we have a $\pi(X)$-set $p^{-1}(x)$ where $x$ is a point of $X$. Assume $p^{-1}(x) = \bigsqcup \pi(X)y$, we have $$F(p^{-1}(x)) = \bigsqcup \widetilde{X}/\pi(X)_y.

As elements of π(X)y\pi(X)_yπ(X)y​ fix y∈p−1(x)y\in p^{-1}(x)y∈p−1(x), the unique morphism of covering spaces of XXX from X~\widetilde{X}X to YYY mapping x~\tilde{x}x~ to yyy factors through X~/π(X)y\widetilde{X}/\pi(X)_yX/π(X)y​. In this way, we have a canonical morphism of covering spaces of XXX:

F(p−1(x))⟶Y.F(p^{-1}(x))\longrightarrow Y. F(p−1(x))⟶Y.

It is not difficult to see that YYY is connected if and only if π(X)\pi(X)π(X) acts transitive on p−1(x)p^{-1}(x)p−1(x). Therefore, the orbit decomposition of p−1(x)p^{-1}(x)p−1(x) corresponds to the connected components decomposition of YYY. In this way, we see the moprhism $$F(p^{-1}(x))\longrightarrow Y$$ is an isomoprhism.

Now, we get the Galois correspondence for covering spaces.

Theorem: Let XXX be a connected, locally path-connected and semi-locally simply-connected space. Then we have an equivalence of categories

Cov/X≅π(X)-Set.\mathrm{Cov}/X\cong\pi(X)\text{-}\mathrm{Set}. Cov/X≅π(X)-Set.

It is easy to verify that the universal covering space X~\widetilde{X}X represents the functor Fx\mathcal{F}_xFx​. Moreover, we have $$\mathrm{Aut}_X(\widetilde{X}) \cong \pi(X),$$ and $$\mathrm{Aut}_X(\widetilde{X}) < \mathrm{Aut}(\mathcal{F}_x).$$

However, AutX(X~)\mathrm{Aut}_X(\widetilde{X})AutX​(X) is in general not isomorphic to Aut(Fx)\mathrm{Aut}(\mathcal{F}_x)Aut(Fx​).

What’s more, by only assume XXX is connected, the functor Fx\mathcal{F}_xFx​ still works and is independent of the choice of xxx, while the universal covering X~\widetilde{X}X may not exists.

entry.title: Too many math alphabets Issue
entry.content:
What cause too many math alphabets Issue?

When I try to submit my paper to arXiv, I meet the too many math alphabets Issue. What cause it?

According to this answer[1], this is because I used the bm package, which double the number of math alphabets while there is a sixteen math alphabets limit for Legacy LaTeX.

To solve the issue, I need to avoid use bm package. Indeed, it is better to redefine each math alphabet to cover Latin and Greek in both bold and regular weights.

  1. https://tex.stackexchange.com/a/587402/54169 ↩︎

entry.title: Profinite groups
entry.content:
In this post, we simplily discuss the basic notions of profinite groups.

Profinite spaces

Usually, the prefix ‘‘pro’’ is short for ‘‘projective limit’’, which is another name of ‘‘limit’’. In this sense, ‘‘profinite’’ means ‘‘limit of finite’’. Then, a profinite set should be a limit of finite sets. But in what category? One can take the limit in Set\mathrm{Set}Set, or in Top\mathrm{Top}Top to get a topology on that set. So, we define
Definition: A profinite space is a limit of finite sets (viewed as discrete sets) in Top\mathrm{Top}Top.

But how the open sets in a profinite space look like?

Example: product of finite sets

Recall that the product topology on the Cartesian product ∏iXi\prod_iX_i∏i​Xi​ is given by the basis

\prod_i U_i, $$ where $U_i$ are open sets of $X_i$ and only finitely many $U_i$ are not the entire $X_i$. From this, one can see the topology of a product of finite sets must be *quasi-compact*, *Hausdorff* and *totally disconnected*. ### Stone spaces A **Stone space** is a topological space which is quasi-compact, Hausdorff and totally disconnected. Note that all those properties can be inherited by subspaces. Recall that any limit is a subspace of a product. Then we get **Proposition:** Profinite spaces are Stone spaces. Conversely, let $X$ be a Stone space, we expect it to be a limit. So, first of all, we need a system of spaces under $X$, in particualr, a system of quotients of $X$. A possible quotient is the set of connected components. However, as we will see, this set is not always finite. Instead, we consider the set of *closed-open partitions*. A *closed-open partition* of $X$ is a collection of nonempty pairwise disjoint closed-open subsets of $X$ such that their union is $X$. The topology on a closed-open partition $I$ is the quotient topology induced by the projection $X\to I$. Since $X$ is quasi-compact, each $I$ must be finite. As quotients of $X$, there exist canonical projections between those closed-open partitions making them form a cofiltered system of quotients of $X$. Now, we have a canonical continuous map

X\longrightarrow \varprojlim I.

This map is injective since the totally disconnectedness implies that any two distinct points can be separated by at least a pair of closed-open sets. This map is also surjective since the compatibility of members of the system implies that for any $(U_I)\in \varprojlim I$, the intersection of any finitely many $U_I$ is nonempty and then the quasi-compactness implies that the intersection of all $U_I$ is nonempty and hence gives the preimage of $(U_I)$. Finally, this map lies in the category of quasi-compact Hausdorff spaces. As this category is *balanced*, we conclude that the map is a homeomorphism. In this way, we see: **Proposition:** Stone spaces are profinite spaces. ## Profinite groups Likewise, a **profinite group** is a limit of finite groups in the category of topological groups. Recall the forgetful functors to $\mathrm{Top}$ and $\mathrm{Grp}$ preserve limits, therefore a profinite group is precisely a topological group whose underlying topological space is a profinite space. ### Open subgroups Let $G$ be a profinite group. First, consider the following question: what is the intersection of all closed-open neighborhoods of $1$? Of course it should contain the connected component of $1$ which is $\{1\}$. Then, the compactness implies that the intersection of all closed-open neighborhoods of $1$ is connected. Therefore, this intersection must be $\{1\}$. Next, what's a neighborhood basis of $1$? An obvious one is the system of all closed-open neighborhoods of $1$. The continuousness of operations further implies that the subsystem of all closed-open subgroups of $G$ is also a neighborhood basis of $1$. One may noticed that any open subgroup $U$ of $G$ must be also closed since its complement is the union of the cosets of $U$ which are not $U$. Moreover, since $G$ is quasi-compact, there must be only finitely many cosets. Recall that for any subgroup, the intersection of all its conjugates is a normal subgroup. We see that any open subgroup of $G$ contains an open normal subgroup. Note that for any open norm subgroup $U$ of $G$, $G/U$ is a finite quotient group of $G$. Thus we have a canonical homomoprhism

G\longrightarrow\varprojlim G/U.

This homomorphism is injective. As $G$ is Hausdorff, any two elements of $G$ can be separated by two open sets. Since open normal subgroups form a neighborhood basis of $1$, we can shrink the two open sets to two cosets of an open normal subgroup $U$ of $G$. This homomorphism is also surjective by the quasi-compactness. As we are dealing with quasi-compact Hausdorff groups, which form a balanced category, we conclude that the above homomorphism is an isomorphism. ### Morphisms of profintie groups Let $G, H$ be two profinite groups. Let's consider what's $\mathrm{Hom}(G,H)$? First, we write $G$ and $H$ as $\varprojlim G/U$ and $\varprojlim H/V$ respectively. Then $$\mathrm{Hom}(G,H) = \mathrm{Hom}(\varprojlim_U G/U,\varprojlim_V H/V) = \varprojlim_V\mathrm{Hom}(\varprojlim_U G/U,H/V).

Since each H/VH/VH/V is finite, we conclude that

\mathrm{Hom}(G,H) = \varprojlim_V\varinjlim_U\mathrm{Hom}(G/U,H/V).

The above formula can help us to reduce problems from profinite groups to finite groups. For instance, recall that in the category of finite groups, monomorphisms (resp. epimorphisms) are injective (resp. surjective) homomorphisms. Thus the same statements hold for profinite groups.

Indices of closed subgroups

Let GGG be a profinite group and HHH a closed subgroup of it. Recall that the index (G:H)(G:H)(G:H) is defined to be the least common multiple of (G:U)(G:U)(G:U) where UUU goes over the family of open subgroups of GGG containing HHH. In particular, #G:=(G:1)\#G:=(G:1)#G:=(G:1) is called the order of GGG.

The follwoing results follow from the defiinions and direct computations.

  • Let H,KH,KH,K be closed subgroups of GGG, hence also profinite. If K<HK<HK<H, then (G:K)=(G:H)(H:K)(G:K) = (G:H)(H:K)(G:K)=(G:H)(H:K). If moreover, KKK is normal in GGG, then (G/K:H/K)=(G:H)(G/K:H/K) = (G:H)(G/K:H/K)=(G:H).
  • A closed subgroup HHH in GGG is open if and only if (G:H)(G:H)(G:H) is finite.
  • If {Hi}\{H_i\}{Hi​} is a decreasing filtered family of closed subgroups in GGG and H=⋂iHiH = \bigcap_iH_iH=⋂i​Hi​, then (G:H)(G:H)(G:H) is the least common multiple of (G:Hi)(G:H_i)(G:Hi​).
  • If GGG is a limit of profinite groups GiG_iGi​ such that each transitaion map is surjective, then #G\#G#G is the least common multiple of #Gi\#G_i#Gi​.

Pro-ppp-groups

Let ppp be a prime number. Like profinite groups, a pro-ppp group is a limit of finite ppp groups. Note that this is equivalent to say #G\#G#G is a power of ppp. Then, for a profinite group GGG, the maximal pro-ppp subgroups are called the Sylow ppp subgroups. In more common setting, a Sylow ppp subgroup is defined to be a closed subgroup PPP of GGG which is a pro-ppp group and p∤(G:P)p\nmid(G:P)p∤(G:P). The usual Sylow Theorems hold in this setting saying the equivalence of the above two definitions and that any two Sylow ppp subgroups are conjugate.

Reference

For the notion of profinite groups and supernatural numbers, see

  • Michael D. Fried, Moshe Jarden, Field Arithmetic, Ergebnisse der Mathematik und ihrer Grenzgebiete 3, Folge 11 (3rd ed.), Springer-Verlag, 2008.
